name: Topic Study
description: A structured enquiry into a defined topic, period, or place. Begins with an engaging hook to capture interest, builds contextual knowledge, moves through source analysis and interpretation, and culminates in a substantiated argument or conclusion. The core humanities template.
assessment_approach: Extended writing task presenting a reasoned argument supported by evidence from the topic. Can take the form of an essay, structured explanation, or debate position.
agent_prompt: Use the TOPIC STUDY template: open with a hook that creates curiosity about the topic, build background context using key facts and vocabulary, guide analysis of sources or evidence, support interpretation by prompting pupils to make connections and inferences, then scaffold an argument or conclusion supported by evidence.

name: Case Study
description: An in-depth investigation of a specific real-world example, location, or scenario. Starts with locating and describing the case in context, collects and organises relevant data, analyses patterns and processes, compares with other cases where appropriate, and reaches an evaluative conclusion.
assessment_approach: Written case study report with data presentation (tables, graphs, maps), analysis of findings, and evaluative conclusion that addresses the original enquiry question.
agent_prompt: Use the CASE STUDY template: begin by locating and describing the case (where, what, who), introduce the enquiry question and key terms, guide data collection from multiple sources, support analysis of the data to identify patterns and processes, prompt comparison with other examples where relevant, and scaffold an evaluative conclusion.

name: Fair Test
description: The classic scientific enquiry: formulating a testable question, making a prediction based on scientific understanding, designing a method that controls variables, collecting and recording data systematically, analysing results, and drawing a conclusion linked back to the original hypothesis.
assessment_approach: Structured scientific report including question, hypothesis with reasoning, method with variables identified, results table/graph, and conclusion evaluating whether results support the hypothesis.
agent_prompt: Use the FAIR TEST template: start with a testable question, guide pupils to form a hypothesis using 'I think... because...', support method design by identifying independent/dependent/control variables, scaffold systematic data collection and recording, prompt analysis using tables and graphs, and guide a conclusion that links back to the hypothesis and underlying science.

name: Observation Over Time
description: Systematic observation and recording of changes or patterns over an extended period. Pupils make careful observations, record findings using drawings, measurements, or logs, classify what they observe, and identify patterns or trends. Particularly suited to biological processes and artistic study of the natural world.
assessment_approach: Observation log or journal with dated entries, annotated drawings or measurements, classification of observations, and summary identifying the key patterns or changes observed.
agent_prompt: Use the OBSERVATION OVER TIME template: set up the observation context and explain what to look for, model careful observation techniques and recording methods (drawing, measuring, photographing), guide classification of observations into categories, and prompt identification of patterns or changes over time. Emphasise scientific vocabulary for what is seen, not what is expected.

name: Pattern Seeking
description: Enquiry focused on identifying relationships and regularities in data. Pupils pose questions about possible correlations, gather data through observation or measurement, organise and represent data graphically, identify patterns, and attempt to explain the underlying relationship.
assessment_approach: Data presentation with appropriate graph or chart, written description of the pattern found, and explanation of the possible reasons for the pattern, including evaluation of the strength of evidence.
agent_prompt: Use the PATTERN SEEKING template: start with a question about a possible relationship, guide systematic data gathering across enough examples to identify a pattern, scaffold graphing or tabulation of results, prompt identification and description of patterns in precise language, and support explanation of why the pattern might exist. Distinguish correlation from causation where appropriate.

name: Research Enquiry
description: A structured approach to answering questions through secondary research. Pupils formulate a research question, select appropriate sources, take and organise notes, synthesise findings from multiple sources, and present their conclusions. Develops information literacy alongside subject knowledge.
assessment_approach: Research report or presentation that answers the original question using evidence from multiple sources, with evaluation of source reliability where appropriate.
agent_prompt: Use the RESEARCH ENQUIRY template: begin with a clear research question, guide selection of appropriate and reliable sources, scaffold note-taking techniques that avoid copying, support synthesis of information from multiple sources into a coherent narrative, and structure a presentation or report that answers the original question with evidence.

name: Text Study
description: A reading-to-writing cycle for primary and KS3 English. Begins with shared or guided reading of a high-quality text, moves through analysis of language features and authorial choices, builds vocabulary, then scaffolds the writing process from planning through drafting to editing and publication.
assessment_approach: Final written outcome in the genre studied, demonstrating understanding of text features, appropriate vocabulary use, and effective application of the writing process.
agent_prompt: Use the TEXT STUDY template: begin with shared reading of the mentor text, pausing to notice and discuss language features and authorial choices. Build vocabulary through context and explicit teaching. Guide analysis of how the text achieves its effects. Scaffold planning using the text as a model. Support drafting with reference to text features identified. Guide editing for accuracy and effect.

name: Worked Example Set
description: A mastery-oriented mathematics sequence moving through the concrete-pictorial-abstract progression with activation and reasoning extension phases. Begins by activating prior knowledge, introduces new concepts with physical manipulatives, transitions to pictorial representations, develops abstract fluency, applies in context, and extends through reasoning challenges.
assessment_approach: Graduated practice set moving from guided examples to independent application, with reasoning task requiring explanation of method and justification of answers.
agent_prompt: Use the WORKED EXAMPLE SET template: begin with an activation task linking to prior learning, introduce the concept using concrete manipulatives the pupil can interact with, transition to pictorial representations that bridge to abstraction, develop abstract fluency through carefully varied practice, apply the concept in a real-world or cross-curricular context, and extend with a reasoning challenge that requires explanation and justification.

name: Open Investigation
description: A pupil-led enquiry where learners frame their own questions, design methods, collect and analyse data, and critically evaluate their methodology. Develops scientific and geographical enquiry skills through increasing autonomy. More open-ended than a fair test.
assessment_approach: Investigation report including the enquiry question, methodology with justification, data presentation, analysis, conclusion, and critical evaluation of the method used.
agent_prompt: Use the OPEN INVESTIGATION template: support pupils in framing their own enquiry question, guide method design by asking 'How could you find out?', scaffold data collection with appropriate recording tools, prompt analysis of results including unexpected findings, and critically evaluate the method — 'What would you do differently? How reliable are your results?'

name: Fieldwork
description: Learning through direct observation and data collection in the field (or simulated field environment). Includes preparation and planning, systematic data collection using fieldwork techniques, data processing and presentation, analysis of findings, and a conclusion that addresses the enquiry question.
assessment_approach: Fieldwork report including methodology, data presentation using appropriate techniques (maps, graphs, tables, photographs), analysis of patterns, and conclusion with evaluation of data reliability.
agent_prompt: Use the FIELDWORK template: prepare pupils with the enquiry question, safety considerations, and data collection methods. Guide systematic field data collection using appropriate techniques (sampling, measuring, recording). Support data processing into presentable forms (maps, charts, tallies). Prompt analysis of what the data shows. Scaffold a conclusion that answers the enquiry question and evaluates data quality.

name: Discussion and Debate
description: A structured sequence for exploring contested issues or multiple perspectives. Begins with a stimulus that raises a question or dilemma, builds knowledge through research, develops arguments through structured discussion techniques, captures thinking in writing, and reflects on how views may have changed.
assessment_approach: Balanced written argument or persuasive piece demonstrating understanding of multiple perspectives, supported by evidence, with a reasoned personal conclusion.
agent_prompt: Use the DISCUSSION AND DEBATE template: present a stimulus that provokes genuine disagreement or multiple viewpoints. Guide research to build evidence for different positions. Structure discussion using techniques like think-pair-share, Socratic questioning, or formal debate roles. Scaffold written capture of the strongest arguments on each side. Prompt reflection on how understanding has developed.

name: Creative Response
description: A creative arts or writing sequence that develops technique through exposure to exemplary work, guided exploration of techniques, structured planning, independent creation, and peer critique. Balances creative freedom with technical skill development.
assessment_approach: Final creative outcome (artwork, design, written piece) accompanied by a reflective evaluation discussing techniques used, influences, and areas for development.
agent_prompt: Use the CREATIVE RESPONSE template: expose pupils to high-quality exemplars, guiding them to notice specific techniques. Provide hands-on exploration of those techniques with guided practice. Support planning that balances creative intention with technical considerations. Allow sustained creation time with minimal interruption but targeted support. Facilitate constructive critique using subject-specific vocabulary.

name: Practical Application
description: A hands-on sequence where pupils apply knowledge and skills to solve a practical problem or create a functional outcome. Begins with a real-world context, builds skills through rehearsal, guides design or planning, supports making or problem-solving, and concludes with evaluation against success criteria.
assessment_approach: Practical outcome (solution, product, program) evaluated against defined success criteria, with written or verbal explanation of the process and decisions made.
agent_prompt: Use the PRACTICAL APPLICATION template: set a real-world context that motivates the task. Rehearse the specific skills needed through guided practice. Support design or planning with clear success criteria. Guide the making or solving process with checkpoints. Facilitate evaluation against the original criteria — 'Does it work? How could it be improved?'

name: Comparison Study
description: A structured comparison of two or more examples, places, periods, or perspectives. Introduces each example with sufficient context, applies a systematic comparison framework, analyses similarities and differences with supporting evidence, and reaches an evaluative conclusion about the significance of those differences.
assessment_approach: Comparative analysis using a structured framework (table, Venn diagram, or essay), demonstrating understanding of both examples and reaching a substantiated evaluative conclusion.
agent_prompt: Use the COMPARISON STUDY template: introduce each example with enough context for meaningful comparison. Provide a systematic framework for comparison (e.g. comparison table, criteria grid). Guide analysis of similarities and differences using evidence. Scaffold evaluative conclusions — 'Which is more significant? Why do these differences exist? What does this comparison tell us?'

name: Source Enquiry
description: A disciplinary history enquiry centred on working with primary and secondary sources. Pupils select relevant sources, contextualise them within their historical period, interrogate them for reliability, utility, and bias, cross-reference between sources, interpret what they reveal, and construct an argument based on the evidence.
assessment_approach: Source-based extended writing that demonstrates ability to analyse provenance, cross-reference sources, reach substantiated interpretations, and construct a historical argument.
agent_prompt: Use the SOURCE ENQUIRY template: present a curated source pack relevant to the enquiry question. Guide contextualisation — when, where, who created this, and why? Scaffold interrogation using NOP (Nature, Origin, Purpose) or similar framework. Prompt cross-referencing between sources — 'Do these agree? Why might they differ?' Support interpretation that goes beyond surface meaning. Guide construction of an argument supported by source evidence.

name: Modelling Enquiry
description: An enquiry that uses models to understand phenomena that cannot be directly observed or tested. Pupils observe a phenomenon, construct a model to represent it, use the model to make predictions, test those predictions against evidence, and revise the model based on findings. Develops understanding of the role of models in science and geography.
assessment_approach: Annotated model with written explanation of how the model represents the real phenomenon, what it predicts, how well predictions matched evidence, and how the model was improved.
agent_prompt: Use the MODELLING ENQUIRY template: present the phenomenon to be explained. Guide construction of a model (physical, diagrammatic, or mathematical) that represents the key features. Prompt predictions — 'If your model is correct, what should happen when...?' Test predictions against available evidence or further observation. Support model revision — 'What does your model get right? What needs changing? Why?'

name: Identifying and Classifying
description: A scientific enquiry focused on identifying specimens, materials, or phenomena and organising them into meaningful groups. Pupils make careful observations, develop grouping criteria, apply classification systems, and understand why classification is useful in science.
assessment_approach: Classification key, sorting diagram, or identification guide created by the pupil, with written explanation of the criteria used and justification for groupings.
agent_prompt: Use the IDENTIFYING AND CLASSIFYING template: provide specimens or examples for observation. Guide careful observation using scientific vocabulary. Prompt initial grouping — 'How could you sort these?' Support development of explicit criteria — 'What makes something belong in this group?' Introduce or develop formal classification systems. Apply the classification to new examples — 'Where would this one go? Why?'

name: Secondary Data Analysis
description: An enquiry using existing published data sets rather than first-hand collection. Pupils frame an enquiry question, select and evaluate appropriate data sources, process and present data using statistical or graphical methods, analyse patterns and anomalies, evaluate reliability, and present findings.
assessment_approach: Data analysis report including processed data presented in appropriate formats, statistical analysis where relevant, interpretation of findings, and evaluation of data reliability and limitations.
agent_prompt: Use the SECONDARY DATA ANALYSIS template: frame a clear enquiry question that requires data. Guide selection of appropriate and reliable data sources. Support data processing using suitable statistical methods and graphical representations. Prompt analysis of patterns, trends, and anomalies. Guide evaluation of data reliability — 'How was this data collected? What are its limitations?' Scaffold presentation of findings that answers the enquiry question.

name: Place Study
description: An in-depth geographical study of a specific place at local, national, or global scale. Pupils orient themselves within the place, use maps and spatial data, collect information about its physical and human features, analyse geographical processes, compare with other places, and evaluate change or issues.
assessment_approach: Place study report combining map work, data presentation, descriptive and explanatory writing about geographical features and processes, and comparative or evaluative conclusion.
agent_prompt: Use the PLACE STUDY template: orient pupils to the place — where is it? What do we already know? Guide mapping activities appropriate to the scale. Support data collection about physical and human features using varied sources. Prompt analysis of geographical processes at work. Facilitate comparison — 'How is this place similar to or different from...?' Guide evaluation of change, sustainability, or geographical issues affecting the place.

name: Performance
description: A sequence building towards a culminating performance in music, drama, or physical activity. Pupils study repertoire or material, develop technical skills through focused practice, rehearse with attention to expression and communication, perform to an audience (real or virtual), and evaluate their own and others' performances.
assessment_approach: Performance assessed against subject-specific criteria (musical accuracy, expression, dramatic impact, physical skill execution) plus reflective self-evaluation.
agent_prompt: Use the PERFORMANCE template: introduce the repertoire or material to be performed. Develop specific techniques needed through focused practice with modelling and feedback. Guide rehearsal that refines both technical accuracy and expressive quality. Support the performance itself with appropriate warm-up and confidence-building. Facilitate evaluation using subject-specific language — 'What went well? What could be more effective? How did the audience respond?'

name: Design, Make, Evaluate
description: The core Design & Technology cycle. Pupils investigate existing products and user needs, design a solution with clear specifications, plan the making process, construct using appropriate materials and techniques, test against the design brief, and evaluate the outcome with suggestions for improvement.
assessment_approach: Design portfolio including investigation findings, annotated design with specifications, making log, test results, and evaluative conclusion comparing outcome to original brief.
agent_prompt: Use the DESIGN, MAKE, EVALUATE template: investigate existing products and user needs to establish a design brief. Guide design development through sketching, annotating, and selecting materials. Support planning with step-by-step making instructions. Guide the making process with attention to safe tool use and technique quality. Facilitate testing against the design brief criteria. Scaffold evaluation — 'Does it meet the brief? What would you change? What did you learn about the materials?'

name: Ethical Enquiry
description: A structured approach to exploring moral and ethical questions. Begins with a stimulus that raises a genuine ethical dilemma, gathers diverse perspectives including religious, philosophical, and secular viewpoints, develops reasoning using ethical frameworks, engages in structured discussion, and produces a considered written response.
assessment_approach: Extended writing presenting a balanced exploration of the ethical question, demonstrating understanding of multiple perspectives and ethical frameworks, with a reasoned personal response.
agent_prompt: Use the ETHICAL ENQUIRY template: present a stimulus that raises a genuine ethical question without a simple right answer. Guide exploration of diverse perspectives — religious, philosophical, cultural, personal. Introduce relevant ethical frameworks (utilitarian, rights-based, virtue ethics) at an appropriate level. Structure discussion that respects different viewpoints. Scaffold a written response that demonstrates balanced understanding and reasoned personal judgement.

name: Text Study (Literature)
description: A KS4 literature study sequence designed for GCSE English Literature preparation. Contextualises the text within its literary and historical period, develops close reading skills, applies literary analysis using subject terminology, supports comparison across texts, and scaffolds essay writing in exam-appropriate formats.
assessment_approach: Timed essay response in GCSE format demonstrating close textual analysis, use of literary terminology, contextual understanding, and structured argument with embedded quotations.
agent_prompt: Use the TEXT STUDY (LITERATURE) template: set the literary and historical context of the text. Guide close reading with attention to language, form, and structure using precise literary terminology. Support literary analysis that considers authorial intent and reader response. Facilitate comparison with other texts where relevant. Scaffold essay writing using GCSE-appropriate structures — clear thesis, embedded quotations, analysis of effect, contextual links.

name: Writer's Workshop
description: A process-writing sequence that develops pupils as independent writers. Studies a mentor text to identify craft techniques, practises those techniques in isolation, plans an original piece, drafts with attention to audience and purpose, engages in peer review for feedback, revises and edits, and publishes the final piece.
assessment_approach: Final published piece demonstrating identified craft techniques, with writing portfolio showing development through the drafting and revision process.
agent_prompt: Use the WRITER'S WORKSHOP template: study a mentor text, drawing attention to specific craft moves (sentence structure, vocabulary choices, paragraph organisation, voice). Guide pupils to identify and name the techniques used. Support planning that incorporates chosen techniques. Provide sustained drafting time with targeted mini-lessons. Facilitate peer review using specific feedback protocols. Guide revision (improving content and craft) then editing (correcting accuracy). Celebrate publication of the finished piece.
